text: Yeah, you're right. I do have lots of thoughts on it, having seen it done sort of well and badly over my career. I think, as I said before, probably my main point is backtesting. The concept of a backtest is a tool. Like any tool, it's not a perfect thing. It should be used carefully to avoid data mining. Really, that's it in a nutshell. So as I mentioned before, that experiment design process is key to talk about the idea before you go into backtest. Why? Because we only have one data sample. It would be different if we go to Mars or Mercury and get a different history of corporate bonds, but we don't have that. Sample period is typically being looked at before. And although you can use all sorts of controls, like in and out of sample analysis, those things will always be imperfect. So have some sense that backtesting is potentially a dangerous thing. We try and do ancillary testing where possible. So we try and prove out the mechanism of an idea rather than just jump straight to the backtest. So to give an example of that, if we think we've got a new signal which can forecast, say, future cash flows for a future backtest, we can do that. So we can do that. So we can do that. So we can do that. And if it's positive, therefore cash flows should improve and spread should narrow. Don't just take the signal and backtest it. Do the ancillary analysis and say, well, does that claimed signal actually forecast cash flows? And if you can do that, you've proven the mechanism, not just the backtest result. It's far more likely you're going to understand your idea better that way.
